text:
Jerk Chicken was cruising down the sunlit streets of Kingston, the aroma of spices wafting through the open windows of his old, beat-up car. He had just finished a long day at the grill, serving up his famous jerk chicken to eager customers. The reggae music pulsed through the speakers, and he hummed along, feeling the rhythm of the island.

Suddenly, flashing lights appeared in his rearview mirror. Jerk Chicken sighed, pulling over to the side of the road. “Just a routine stop,” he muttered to himself, adjusting his colorful bandana. The officer approached, a stern look on his face.

“Good evening, sir. License and registration, please,” the officer said, glancing around the car. Jerk Chicken fumbled through his glove compartment, trying to keep his cool. As he handed over the documents, the officer’s eyes fell on the passenger seat, where a glint of metal caught his attention.

“What’s that?” the officer asked, pointing to the handgun resting on the seat.

Jerk Chicken’s heart raced. “Oh, that’s just for protection,” he stammered, his mind racing. “You know, the streets can be rough sometimes.”

The officer raised an eyebrow, clearly skeptical. “You have a permit for that?”

Jerk Chicken swallowed hard, realizing he was in deeper than he thought. “Uh, well… I was just about to get one,” he replied, his voice shaky. The officer’s expression softened slightly, but the tension hung thick in the air, as the sun dipped below the horizon.
